node.title: Families will be forced to isolate for 14 days at home if just one member gets COVID-19 in Queensland
node.alt: Queensland Health Minister Yvette D'Ath speaks at a press conference at COVID-19 vaccination hub.
node.description: Queensland Health Minister Yvette D'Ath says "opening up" will only work if the state continued to test, trace, isolate and quarantine.
node.content:
["With Queensland slowly edging towards its vaccination targets, those who have had two doses will still have to quarantine for two weeks if they get COVID-19.", "As will their family, which\u00a0means partners and their children, or flatmates or grandparents if they live with in the same home and are deemed at risk.", "But what about \"close contacts\" \u2014 like a teacher or a doctor who comes into contact with someone who gets the dangerous Delta variant?", "Queensland Health Minister Yvette D'Ath said \"opening up\" will only work if the state continues\u00a0to test, trace, isolate and quarantine.", "Well, the jury's out on this as health data and advice keeps changing.", "What Ms D'Ath does know is tough stay-at-home orders for the fully vaccinated will remain in force as Queensland battles the worst-case scenario of 1,200 cases a day when borders reopen on December 17.", "\"All of the advice the Doherty modelling, as well as QIMR's modelling that we have received, says that all of the lifting of restrictions have to operate on the basis we are still testing,\" Ms D'Ath said.", "\"So we expect certainly at the 70 per cent and 80 per cent\u00a0 [of Queenslanders over 16 that have had two doses of a COVID-19 vaccine] \u2026 will still be quarantining for 14 days, based on advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee until that advice changes.", "\"If the advice is you can then quarantine for a shorter period of time, or you do not need to\u00a0put as many people into quarantine if they are close contacts, then we will take that advice.", "", "
Restrictions and lockdowns in areas with low vaccination rates remain an option, but only as a last resort.(AP: Frank Augstein/Pool)
", "
Be patient, as the rules keep changing
", "Ms D'Ath said some jurisdictions had said quarantines and lockdowns may differ for people who were vaccinated.", "\"People who are fully vaccinated may still be able to go to work if they are a close contact,\" she said", "\"Where, if you are unvaccinated you have to quarantine \u2014 so we will work through all those things.", "\"Of course if you are positive, or if a child is sick with COVID and quarantining at home and their parent is a teacher or a doctor, it is up to the parents to make the decision who quarantines with that child.", "\"But if they have been close contacts, we will take that advice at the time.", "\"But it may very well be different if you are fully vaccinated, compared to unvaccinated.\"", "In one of her last press conferences as Queensland's chief health officer, Jeanette Young said double dosed COVID-19 patients would most likely be able to stay at home and recover being managed through a \"virtual ward\" rather than be forced to go to hospital.", "Restrictions and lockdowns in areas with low vaccination rates remain an option, but only as a last resort.", "
Clear as mud, but nobody's fault
", "University of Queensland virologist Kirsty Short said there were no clear answers on fully vaccinated infectious people being forced to stay at home.", "\"Because we also know if you are vaccinated and you and a contact case is vaccinated the risk of transmission is much lower, but it is still not zero,\" Dr Short said.", "\"It may be that a close contact would not have to quarantine but they would need to take a daily rapid antigen self-test.", "\"That is a scenario I could see happening then if they tested positive with the test they would have to quarantine.", "\"But again I think we need more data on how to ascertain what the actual risk is for the fully vaccinated.\"", "", "
There\u00a0are no clear answers on fully vaccinated infectious people being forced to stay at home yet.(AAP: Albert Perez)
", "
New territory with boosters on the way
", "Dr Short said the advice was changing every day in terms of the data.", "\"You look at the situation of boosters for every member of the population and that is going to change how the vaccine works and the efficacy of it,\" she said.", "\"It increases the efficacy of the vaccine against severe disease but it also increases your protection against getting the illness.", "\"But what we do not know is how long that lasts.", "\"Is that a transient thing or is that protection against transmission going to persist?", "\"Because that is going to affect how COVID goes through the community?\"", "She said as January approached, more people would be up for the booster shot.", "\"There is a lot we do not know and it is contingent on how many people are going to get the boosters,\" she said.", "", "
As the vaccination and booster rates soar, Dr Short said she could see a seven-day isolation limit.(Supplied: University of Queensland)
", "
COVID-19 or a bad flu \u2014\u00a0just don't come in
", "Dr Short said she believed\u00a0there would be a fundamental change in culture when the borders flung open again.", "\"Prior to the pandemic if you were sick you would be a trooper and come to work and just work through it,\" she said.", "\"Whereas now it is very much you are sick, you stay at home, so you do not infect anyone else \u2014\u00a0even if it is just a cold.\"", "She said no-one would want anyone to go their workplace spreading it around.", "\"I think there will be a bit of a change in attitude about what is socially acceptable when you are ill,\" she said.", "\"Maybe it will be easier for you to work at home \u2014\u00a0not necessarily isolate \u2014\u00a0but limit what you do for two weeks.", "As the vaccination and booster rates soar, Dr Short said she could see a seven-day isolation limit.", "But she maintained in the \"new norm\" where we \"live\" with COVID-19, staff would most likely have to negotiate with their workplace about coming in once they felt better, or continued to work from home.", "", "
As January approaches, more people will be up for the booster shot.(AAP: Albert Perez)
", "
Confusing for business
", "Chamber of Commerce and Industry Queensland (CCIQ) said with Queensland just weeks away from reopening for business there were no clear rules about how to deal with double vaccinated staff who fell sick.", "CCIQ spokeswoman Amanda Rohan said while industry would always adhere to health advice, hearing \"new information this late in the game with no details about what it means for business\" does nothing to support long-term recovery efforts.", "\"New information and updates which directly or indirectly impact business and consumer confidence must be backed up with clear directions and guidelines through the state government roadmap,\" she said.", "\"\u202fIt will be too late for those businesses to be notified about any new rules,\u202fobligations\u202for requirements.", "\"They need those details now, to allow them time to invest in staff and assets, and prepare to get back into business.\"", "", "
Small businesses across Queensland need time,\u202fresources\u202fand support to help them as the border reopens.(AAP: Albert Perez)
", "
'Ping pong pandemic politics'
", "Queensland Opposition Leader David Crisafulli has criticised the state government for constantly changing the roadmap to recovery.", "\"Queenslanders are growing tired of that \u2014 I want the state government to start motivating and not dictating,\" he said.", "\"You can't keep moving guidelines all the time, that does nobody any good.", "\"My first priority is getting the thousands of Queenslanders who are stuck over the border back home.\"", "", "
Outbreak: How Australia lost control of the Delta variant
"]
